  Their power waning, th knight today ar locked
in a bitter internal feud: Is it better to maintain their
strict codes •even in the face of obsolescence, s cur
tn the knowledge they were true to themselves? Or
 hould they embrace a changing world and fight to
defend it, even if the knights mu t chan.ge with it?

THE OATH A        D THE MEASURE
Th Knight of olamnia follow a chivalric code
with two parts: the Oath and the Measure. both
inspired by the writing of ina        olamm.1s. The
Oath i imple and aspirattonaJ- a star to navigate
by- hile the Mea ur lay out pecifi ruies for the
organization and conduct of the knighthood.
   Th e Oath. The Oath of the Knights of olamnia
has be n the am ince ina             olamm.1s founded
the knighthood: ''Est Sularus oth Mithas," or "My
   onor ls My ife ." Thi principle- to sacrifice all
for the sake of honor- guides the actions of every
knight, at lea t in theory.
   The Measure. In contrast to the Oath, the Mea-
sure i a staggeringly compHcat d, e cruciatingly
  pecific guide to knightly life. Originally put forth by
Vinas oiamnus as an organizational scheme and
code of conduct for the knighll orders, the Measure
grew over the year to encompass thirty-seven vol-
umes, covering everything from courtly etiquette
to the proper saddling of mounts. According to the
Measure, the knights no lo_nger have ufficient num-
bers to elect a n w Grand Ma ter, the highest office
in th kn ighthood, leaving them without an author-
ity who could overrule or updat the - easure.
   Despite this, a growing minority of knights push
for a reform or the Measure, b li ving that ifs un-
wieldy and outdated and that i no longer serve the
ideals laid down by their founder.

         de rs, a mage must officially join the Mages of High
           orcery and be subjected to the Test of High or-

         chaUenged. Failing the test can b deadly. but those
         who dare to seek magical power without pa sing
         the test are branded renegades and enemies of the
         Mage of High or ery.

                                                                  BATTLEFI ELD ENCOUNTERS
                                                                  The "Battle of High Hill section presents the first of
                                                                                           0


                                                                  several battlefield encounters in this adventure. These
                                                                  are events that take place on active battlefields. During
                                                                  these scenes, ~he wider battle is abstracted, allowing
                                                                  the characters focus on specific, tide -turni1ng conflicts.
                                                                     At the edge of each mapped batt,1efie ld encounte r
                                                                  an:d beyond is a region ca lled the Fray. The Fray is an
                                                                  interpretation of the dangers of combat, from clashing
                                                                  combatants to deadly spells. It is also the source of
                                                                  additional threats. Each battlefield encounter e,xplains
                                                                  the Fray's effects and pres,en.ts additional dangers that
                                                                  might occur at the end of each round of combat. A bat-
                                                                  tlefield enceunte.r ends when noted in the text.


                                                                Fray. The 15-foot-wide area marked by tt e design at
                                                                 the edge of the map represents dozens of clashing
                                                                 combatants. This area and the battlefield beyond
                                                                 lhe map are difficult terrain. A creature that enters
                                                                 the Fray for the first time on a turn or tarts its
                                                                 turn there must ucceed on a D l6 Dexterity sav-
                                                                 ing throw or take 7 (2d6) slashi.ng damage from
                                                                 opportuoi tic foes. Th Fray an't be damaged
                                                                 and remains untjl the battle ends.
                                                                Wall and Cart. oth the stone walls and the supply
                                                                 cart are difficult terrain. They grant ha lf cover to
                                                                 cr -ature behind t11em.

         SIDEKICKS
         This appendix presents six sidekicks- special
         NPCs who can accompany the player characters on
         their adventures. The following sidekicks are ap-
         propriate for a 1st-level adventuring party. Consider
         addfog one or more s.i dekicks to round out your
         charact rs' group if tlier are fe\. er than four p.lay-
         er . As the DM, you can play sidekicks, or players
         can play them alongside their own charact rs. You
         can read more about sidekick in Tasha's Cauldron
         of Everything.
           Ir a sidekick accompanies the characters into
         later Jevels, the sidekick also advances in leve]. TMs
         represents a combinaho:n of the adventures the side-
         kick has shared with th group and the sidekick's
         own training.
           A id kick's level should alway equal the averag
         level'~.f the adventuring party, and il should go up
         whene er th group's average L el does. Consult
         the tables in the "Sidekick Leve] "section at the end
         of this appendix for guidance on how o update th
         sidekick ' tat blocks when they advance to levels 2
         through 11.
